body: SQLAlchemy or something else?

Coverage decreased (-0.02%) to 69.284% when pulling **5cf777d316ca1dd589186c4e835c14ce7576d230 on mistercrunch:pivot_time** into **91bd38a851754d4a0525d9f49a795943d299cde0 on apache:master**.

I doubt Cassandra and Mongo support any form of SQL. You'd have to implement the connector using whatever query interface they have. I'm assuming Cassandra and Mongo can both do group by and filtering operation.
Seems like removing `can_explore` from a role should work now since we now have a different view for the json (`can_explore_json`)

I agree with @joshwalters and think that clicking "explore" should preserve the context of the filtered dashboard, but perhaps make it clear that you're in a "mutated" slice.

+1 
Are there any way to change the legend in the graph?

My point is there's no issue to be worked around, it's just you are not passing the python path to httpd. Please open a PR to the doc with the proper httpd configuration to help other users with the same issue.

I'd gladly avoid adding another compilation step to the javascript assets. If types are needed, i think fb flow would be the choice.
As a general note issues proposing to use some tools are usually best accompanied with a PR :)

Regarding the compilation steps : Adding a loader type to webpack is not another step but a different path for specific file types, at the moment we are compiling from es6 to es5 and less to css etc and then with typescript we will be compiling from typescript to es5, for ts files.

we have written some components, live data sources, mqtt services in typescript for superset but at the moment this is an hindrance on our side to PR typescript code int js. Plus we (team) have spent a long time understanding reactjs code and created many bugs due to lack of documentation and type checking, as the topic suggest for this issue.
@ahmadalibaloch looking forward your PRs then 👍
Do you mean we can PR typescript coded features and components and they will be accepted by the superset community?
I mean that it's easier to evaluate a change if it comes with code.
@uptonking i have the save problem with yours ,how do you solve your problem,do you change the MANIFEST.in file?

Indeed, I created a view containing unique channels name and it's working like a charm but I didn't find out why cause I use different source / table. But I though right about the name column :) It's perfect. Thank you !

Many of the charts have requirements that won't be fulfilled when landing on the "explore view". I'd rather support only a subset of the charts in the "visualize flow" and make sure that we fill in the values needed for the controls for them to render properly as you land. 

Your approach in building the dropdown is better though. Can you add a `.filter()` that specifies a subset of the vizTypes?

Some of the controls like `metrics` will have pick a default value, but some required ones won't. Eventually we should make sure that all required field get a decent default so that the visualize flow always works.

@mistercrunch I encountered 2 problems with resizing while working on this PR.  
**First**: it wasn't possible to resize `react-ace` properly it had some issues. This one is solved by updating to the version `5.1.2`.  
**Second**: Sql Lab has one hack in it. This hack adjusts sizes of some parts of the page. I didn't fix it, since it is out of scope of the PR, however I have a couple of ideas about it.

Update: tried to resize the browser's window in different ways - seems to work.
@jlkokko can you try `pip install flask-babel==0.11.1`
Is that info even in the metastore? Any idea what the API to discover that would be?
I'm pretty sure this is fixed as we don't use timestamp as an alias anymore, we use `__timestamp`. Closing. @kumarit you have to connect using SQLAlchemy
It's all about the amount of pushdown that is supported on the Presto connectors, you want for the connector to support predicate pushdown, and ideally grouping pushdown (though that's less likely)

Personally I'm not clear on the implications. Also unclear that TS is a solution to address documentation. There's nothing keeping us from documenting the React code we have now. To me the best way to document React is something like:
https://github.com/storybooks/storybook

Definitely want to be careful in jumping on the latest JS bandwagon (glad we passed on CoffeeScript for instance). Coming from Python I'm not super enthusiastic about types.

Also not enthusiastic about adding a layer in the webpack delivery chain. I spent hours in dependency/webpack hell recently and clearly want to keep things lean in that area.

So at least for now I think the odds are against TS unless someone can make a strong case for it and for the Apache committers to rally behind that decision.

Yeah the info is in the metastore, as we can see the column breakdown when seeing the same table through hue. `SHOW COLUMNS FROM table` query in presto lists all the nested column data types as well.
Not quite sure yet whether its currently returned to superset though.

I take it superset uses pyhive for connection to presto as well? If thats the case it's maybe not returned by pyhive: https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/blob/master/pyhive/sqlalchemy_presto.py#L38
The `_type_map` there doesn't seem to list any of the complex/nested row types.

The other problem with filter box causing it to be slow is that it triggers multiple queries for each filter control. I raised a similar issue here https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/3073

Another impact of this behavior seems to be that DB sessions remain opened,  until closed by the DBMS or server shutdown.

If the engine can't be reused across queries, alternatives could be to ensure the engine is disposed after the request and/or the pooling is disabled, using NullPool.
Agreed, we should use `NullPool` for queries
I'm not sure if we have instance of calling create_engine twice in a single web request, but if so it should be easy to put a @caching decorator on the engine property.

Actually it has to run multiple queries as the metric may not be additive (count distinct for instance).  Also there could be cardinality issues as the cartesian product may be very large.

We could parallelize them though to save some time.

I'm thinking we need to re-write the whole Filter box component to offer much more functionality, where each filter needs to have its own configuration elements (allow picking a metric or not, sort order, allow-multi-choices, ...)

Yes we use pyhive. We're committed to allow to go around the lowest common denominator issue with SQLAlchemy. We typically put the specifics in the `superset.db_engine_specs` module. For instance we could add a custom `get_table_columns` method in there that would default to the current SQLAlchemy logic in BaseEngineSpecs, but that would implement a solution that involves `SHOW COLUMNS FROM table` in the case of Presto.

It may not make the top of Airbnb's priority list for a little while, but we'll happily review a PR that adds functionality in that direction.

I pulled the branch and tried it. It mostly works but it's a little funky. We went from single-page app to no-quite that where there's one too many scrollbars on the lower right panel.

I don't think the lower-right panel should have a fixed height anymore. Meaning if/when you scroll down to look at the data in the result pane the SQL Editor would flow out of the screen, leaving more place for to browse the results.
I'd also like to have a minimum height constraint on the SQL editor, so that users can't get confused as to it completely disappearing.
